posts.name: Vitaliy Duvalko
posts.cooked:
As the season goes on and robots evolve, getting shooters that are more accurate from a distance seems like the next step forward.

Our team has made a shooter that can shoot from the wing line at about 10% consistency, and about 50% from just further than the podium.

We’re using horizontal rollers, one on the top and one on the bottom of the note. To get spin, we’ve spaced out the wheels on one side, a pretty standard solution. We’re using stealth wheels.

Still, we have accuracy problems. Has anyone figured out ways to improve shooter accuracy from a distance? Different types of wheels, different spacings, spinning the top/bottom roller faster, etc.?
Is the shooter on an arm or a wrist?
Also could you send a video of it shooting so we can get an idea of how it works?

posts.name: Vitaliy Duvalko
posts.cooked:
Yeah, here’s our robot reveal. Let me know if it’s not clear enough:

No it’s not on an arm or wrist, it’s its own separate component. Therefore, play in the shooter angle isn’t really an issue, it’s more the wheels and contact with the note.

posts.name: Nicholas
posts.cooked: I would suggest looking at some slow motion videos of your shooter shooting and the course that the note takes if you haven’t already. The other thing that might be worth checking is that your top bar and bottom bar are identical. It might just be my eyes deceiving me in your video (1:06), but the bottom wheels on the left have slightly more spacing between them than the top. In my opinion, this really shouldn’t affect it too much at all, unless it is causing the note to tilt vertically. These are just the thoughts that crossed my mind, love the robot and wish you the best of luck!

posts.name: Mike Marandola
posts.cooked:
One simple change that we made after seeing 5895, 103, and 9312 was to swap one side of the shooter to wheels with less friction. We didn’t have any AM 3” stealth wheels other than orange so we printed a 3” PLA+ wheel with the ‘Fuzz’ setting in Bambu Studio.

It instantly stopped all flyers and made the note dead flat in flight. Despite what many people  say, adding spin helps. So does adding PTFE or UHMW to all non-rolling surfaces. We did have to increase our pulleys from 32T-24T to 37T-18T to make up for the speed loss.

IMG_6568 3024×4032 2.08 MB

IMG_6568 3024×4032 2.08 MB

IMG_6568 3024×4032 2.08 MB

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked: Adding spin is huge. The way our team did that was by splitting the flywheels side to side (so one side could be faster than the other) it worked very well for us. There are many solutions. You could even consider spinning it inside your indexer, something our team played with during our prototyping.

posts.name: Vitaliy Duvalko
posts.cooked:
Interesting Do you know how much spin you get?

When we’re shooting from just beyond the podium, we get one rotation from when the note leaves the shooter to when it hits the speaker. Any idea if this is enough? We haven’t tested more than about 1 rotation.

posts.name: Vitaliy Duvalko
posts.cooked:
Cool solution!

Did you run them for an entire competition? How did the 3d printed wheels run at such high speeds?

And I definitely agree with the UHMW lining. Every team should be doing this. In fact, I’ll go back to our shooter and line all the exposed aluminum with some UHMW tape. Thanks

posts.name: Mike Marandola
posts.cooked:
Yup we ran them all of FMA Seneca this past weekend and a full week of practice and auto testing. Probably a couple hundred notes shot through. No signs of damage other than some of the ‘fuzz’ texture smoothing over.

We only printed them so we could test right away and will probably switch to black or gray stealth wheels if it has the same performance.
